dc:description:
*GAS8* was first described as a primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2015 (Olbrich et al., PMID: 26387594). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 33 (MONDO:0014750, OMIM:605178), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Many of the probands displayed respiratory symptoms including sinusitis, productive cough, bronchitis, pneumonia and otitis media during childhood. Other common patient phenotypes included bronchiectasis, decreased nasal nitric oxide, abnormal ciliary motility, and ciliary defects (primarily nexin-dynein regulatory complex defects or outer microtubular pair disorganization). Situs inversus was not present in any of them.

This curation includes six variants (five nonsense, one canonical splice site) that have been reported in seven probands in four publications (PMIDs: 26387594, 37950557, 27120127, 38873586). Biallelic loss-of-function was identified as the suspected mechanism of pathogenicity.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by multiple forms of experimental evidence ranging from biochemical and expression evidence to mouse, zebrafish, *Chlamydomonas*, and *Trypanosoma* models (PMIDs:19043402, 27472056, 37975235, 12847082, 37975235 and 35071054). GAS8 loss was observed in human airway cells from a PCD patient with disease-causing variants in *CCDC65* (PMID: 37975235). GAS8 is similar to CCDC65 in that both proteins are located in the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (PMID: 37975235), and variants in *CCDC65* have similarly been asserted in relation to primary ciliary dyskinesia 27. A *Trypanosoma cruzi* model with loss of the GAS8 ortholog has affected flagella with ultrastructural defects similar to the cilia of human probands (PMID: 35071054). The *Chlamydomonas* ortholog of the GAS8 protein, PF2, shows immunolocalization specifically to the flagella of wild-type cells (PMID: 12847082). The *Chlamydomonas* model of PF2 loss demonstrated abnormal ciliary motility and a ciliary ultrastructural defect in the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (N-DRC) consistent with the localization data, which could be rescued by the wild-type gene (PMID: 12847082). The zebrafish phenotypes of hydrocephalus and otolith defects were consistent with ciliary dysfunction and fluid buildup (PMID:19043402). Finally, the mice exhibited hydrocephalus and ciliary defects matching those observed in the human patients (PMID: 27472056).

In conclusion, *GAS8* is definitively associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia 33. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time without the emergence of conflicting evidence. This classification was approved by the Motile Ciliopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on November 8th, 2024 (SOP version 11).

*GAS8* was first described as a primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2015 (Olbrich et al., PMID: 26387594). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 33 (MONDO:0014750, OMIM:605178), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Many of the probands displayed respiratory symptoms including sinusitis, productive cough, bronchitis, pneumonia and otitis media during childhood. Other common patient phenotypes included bronchiectasis, decreased nasal nitric oxide, abnormal ciliary motility, and ciliary defects (primarily nexin-dynein regulatory complex defects or outer microtubular pair disorganization). Situs inversus was not present in any of them.

This curation includes six variants (five nonsense, one canonical splice site) that have been reported in seven probands in four publications (PMIDs: 26387594, 37950557, 27120127, 38873586). 

The pattern of variants identified loss-of-function as the suspected mechanism of pathogenicity.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by multiple forms of experimental evidence ranging from biochemical and expression evidence to mouse, zebrafish, Chlamydomonas, and Trypanosoma models (PMIDs:19043402, 27472056, 37975235, 12847082, 37975235 and 35071054). GAS8 loss was observed in human airway cells from a PCD patient with disease-causing variants in CCDC65 (PMID: 37975235). GAS8 is similar to CCDC65 in that both proteins are located in the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (PMID: 37975235), and variants in CCDC65 have similarly been asserted in relation to primary ciliary dyskinesia 27. A Trypanosoma cruzi model with loss of the GAS8 ortholog has affected flagella with ultrastructural defects similar to the cilia of human probands (PMID: 35071054). The Chlamydomonas ortholog of the GAS8 protein PF2 shows immunolocalization specifically to the flagella of wild-type cells (PMID: 12847082). The Chlamydomonas model of PF2 loss demonstrated abnormal ciliary motility and a ciliary ultrastructural defect in the nexin-dynein regulatory complex (N-DRC) consistent with the localization data, which could be rescued by the wild-type gene (PMID: 12847082). The zebrafish phenotypes of hydrocephalus and otolith defects were consistent with ciliary dysfunction and fluid buildup (PMID:19043402). Finally, the mice exhibited hydrocephalus and ciliary defects matching those observed in the human patients (PMID: 27472056).

In conclusion, GAS8 variations are definitively associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia 33. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time without the emergence of conflicting evidence. 

This classification was approved by the Motile Ciliopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on November 8th, 2024 (SOP version 11).

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient P0543
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband was noted to have related parents. Physical examination of the patient was normal.

Sperm analysis evidenced a complete astheno-teratozoospermia with 100% of immotile and morphologically abnormal spermatozoa, most of which (93%) displayed multiple morphological abnormalities of the flagellum with 53% of absent, 24% of short, 16% of curled or bent and flagella (Figure 2B).

Further clinical assessment of this patient suggested a condition of nonsyndromic infertility without PCD-symptoms except for a medical past history of asthma and recurrent otitis during childhood.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to consanguinity and homozygosity.

Functional Evidence: To demonstrate the impact of the candidate GAS8 variant on protein expression and localization, we performed IF staining of sperm from controls and P0543using an antibody raised against the C-terminus domain of GAS8 (aa 379–469). In control spermatozoa, GAS8 and the axonemal marker acetylated α-tubulin co-localize within the axoneme (Figure 3). However, spermatozoa from the patient showed no GAS8 signal in the flagellar axoneme indicating that this protein was either absent or truncated (Figure 3).
Downscored due to sequencing methods and consanguinity.

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-929
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband was born to non-consanguineous parents. PCD was diagnosed in 2000 due to classical clinical symptoms. He has a history of recurrent pneumonia since birth, chronic rhinitis, recurrent otitis media with effusion leading to several grommet insertions, and reduced conductive hearing. Middle lobe atelectasis has been demonstrated by chest X-ray. His nasal NO production rate was also low (36.6 nl/min), consistent with PCD.

Additionally, TEM of the patient's cilia showed some ultrastructure defects.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to due to homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: 11-year-old girl
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing (WES) (Twist Bioscience) was performed on proband and her parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband has consanguineous parents.

Proband's PICADAR score was 3. The proband also had low nasal nitric oxide (18 nl/mi).

The sweat chloride test was negative (Cl 24 mmol/L), as were genetic evaluations for CF.

Nasal cytology revealed inflammatory rhinitis with neutrophilic cellularity and few non-degranulated eosinophilic elements.

It was noted that the proband had NON-situs inversus and no IDA defect in assessable axonemes.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to consanguinity.

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD481
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband has no known consanguinity but the parents originated from the same village.

Airway epithelial cells were obtained from a biopsy of the inferior nasal turbinate and evaluated through TEM Analysis of Ciliary Ultrastructure. Airway epithelial cells obtained by airway brushing from PCD481 were examined by Immunofluorescence Microscopy.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to small village origin/possible consanguinity. Upscored due to strength of functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD1109
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted NGS using a custom designed capture panel of PCD-involved genes (Supp. Table S1) and PCD-candidate genes.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Proband was reported to have no known consanguinity or laterality defects. Fertility was not reported due to the patient's age.

Airway epithelial cells were obtained from a bronchial biopsy and evaluated through TEM Analysis of Ciliary Ultrastructure. Airway epithelial cells obtained by airway brushing from PCD1109 were examined by Immunofluorescence Microscopy.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-1627
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The proband has a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, chronic wet cough since early childhood, recurrent bronchitis and pneumonia, and recurrent otitis media with effusion. After insertion of grommets, he had suffered from purulent otorrhea for several months. Audiometry revealed conductive hearing loss without signs of inner ear impairment. Computed tomography of the lungs at the age of 7 years demonstrated consolidation of the middle and lingual lobes with early bronchiectasis. His nasal NO production rate was low (100 nl/min), consistent with PCD.

Additionally, TEM of the patient's cilia showed some ultrastructure defects.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to sequencing methods and small village origin/possible consanguinity.
As seen in Figures 5B and 5D), the absence of the GAS8 equivalent ("PF2") causes ciliary beating defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rupp et al. 2003

evidence.dc:description: Downscored to avoid potential double counting of evidence.
Both GAS8 and CCDC65 are both involved with cilia formation in the Nexin-Dynein Regulatory Complex.
evidence.rdfs:label: Jreijiri et al. 2023

evidence.dc:description: Lack of similarity between model and human probands
The ciliary structures in the WT and Rescue are better defined than the knockouts in 3b and 3c. Figure 3 (a-d). Table II also notes that slow forward swimming was resolved in the rescue.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rupp et al. 2003

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to the lack of similarity between the model and the human probands.

The model organism of hydrocephalus is similar to the human phenotype of pneumonia since both conditions lead to fluid building up within the body. The model had ciliary defects similar to the ciliary defects that the human patients experience.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lewis et al. 2016

evidence.dc:description: The model organism of hydrocephalus is similar to the human phenotype of pneumonia since both conditions lead to fluid building up within the body. The model had otolith defects which is similar to the ciliary defects that the human patients experience.
evidence.rdfs:label: Colantonio et al. 2008

evidence.dc:description: The defect in the model is noted to affect the dynein regulatory complex (DRC) which is a known biochemical localization of GAS8. Downscored due to lack of similarity between model and human.

Both the model and the human display matching ciliary defects: abnormal ciliary motility and abnormal ciliary structure. The ultrastructural defect is highly specified to the Chlamydomonas model and can also serve as a match to localization
evidence.rdfs:label: Rupp et al. 2003

evidence.dc:description: Downscored due to lack of similarity between model and human probands
The model's affected flagella is similar to the ultrastructural defects found in human probands.
evidence.rdfs:label: Saenz-Garcia et al. 2021
